Description.val:
Funds were realigned from BLI 5530 to BLI 5231 beginning in FY15, and have been realigned back to BLI 5530 beginning in FY20.

The Anti-Ship Missile Decoy Program covers a family of decoys and the equipment to deploy them. It is an essential element of the Anti-Ship Missile Defense tactics to counter the threat of enemy homing missiles. Nulka is a joint program with Australia, and is currently in service with the Australian, Canadian, and United States Navies. Nulka consists of the Decoy Launching System (DLS) (MK 53) and Offboard Active Decoy (MK 234).  This line contains various equipment and subsystems for a system which will provide the capability to defeat the effectiveness of hostile Anti-Ship cruise missiles. The MK 53 DLS consists of a Decoy Launch Processer (DLP), launching power supplies, and from two to six launchers depending on the ship class.  Each launcher is capable of storing and launching two Nulka decoys.  The MK 53 DLS provides the launch authorization and flight demands to the Nulka decoy when a Nulka engagement is initiated by the EW operator.  The MK 53 DLS has been installed on the CG 47, DDG 51, FFG 7, LSD 41, and LSD 49 Classes in prior years.  Installation of the MK 53 DLS on CVNs began in FY14 and it will be installed on eight carriers. Six of the final seven DLS units are being procured under BLI 5231. The last DLS will be procured under this budget (BLI 5530), which starts in FY20. 

The last full decoy will be procured in FY20 under VV002.  Funding from VV002 in the FY 2020 President's Budget request was realigned to VV200, VV201, VV202, VV203, VV005, VV006, and VV003. Starting in FY20, decoy procurement will be broken out into separate procurement of subassemblies.  The Legacy Nulka decoy consists of the kit assembly, rocket motor assembly (RMAs), canister assembly and legacy payload. The legacy Nulka decoy can no longer be procured due to obsolescence issues.  Starting in FY20, these obsolescence issues will be addressed by new production of kit assemblies (VV200), RMAs (VV201), and canister assemblies (VV202).  Starting in FY21, the legacy payload obsolescence will be addressed by procurement of Nulka X/Y payloads (VV005). The Advanced Nulka decoy consists of the advanced flight assembly and Advanced Nulka payload.  Production of Advanced Flight Assemblies (VV203) will begin in FY21.  Production of Advanced Nulka Payloads (VV006) will begin in FY22 to counter advanced threats.

VV001: Funding is for procurement of MK 53 DLS.

VV002: Funding is for procurement of MK 234 Nulka decoy. FY20 funding will procure the last MK 234 Nulka decoy. 

VV003: Funding is for Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs)/Ordinance Alterations (ORDALT) to address obsolescence, quality assurance, reliability, safety, Electromagnetic Interference (EMI), and diminishing manufacturing source issues. ECP funding will support DLS hardware updates including Circuit Card Assembly (CCA) redesigns, Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) initialization improvements, Power Supply System (PSS) modernization. Logistics funding will support maintenance of decoy and special purpose test equipment, non-recurring costs to produce engineering equipment, and configuration management tools for Flight Control Units, Propulsion Igniter Units, Thrust Control Units, Thermal Batteries, Spin Control Units, Rocket Motor Assemblies, Canister Assemblies, and Advanced Flight Assemblies. 

VV830: Funding is for Production Engineering support to the MK 234 Nulka Decoy, Nulka Kit Assemblies, Rocket Motor Assembly, Canister Assembly, Nulka X/Y Payloads, and Advanced Nulka Payloads.  

VV500: Funding is for procurement of Advanced Offboard EW mass models, ALQ-248 pods, and Production Support. Production Support activities include: pre-installation work ups and documentation, updates to training materials, and sparing support. Funding for this program ends in FY22.

VV200: Funding is for procurement of Nulka Kit Assemblies (includes: varying quantities and combinations of: Flight Control Units, Propulsion Igniter Units, Thrust Control Units, Spin Control Units, and Thermal Batteries based on requirements).

VV201: Funding is for procurement of Rocket Motor Assembly.

VV202: Funding is for procurement of Canister Assembly.

VV203: Funding is for procurement of Advanced Flight Assemblies.

VV005: Funding is for procurement of Nulka X/Y Payloads. The EW payload was developed under an ONR program that targets specific threats that the current payload on the Nulka decoy does not. The payload provides an advanced Electronic Warfare (EW) transmitter and increased signal processing capability.

VV006: Funding is for procurement of Advanced Nulka Payloads.

VVINS: Funding is for the installation of Nulka Systems, and Fleet Modernization Program installs.

Name.@footnote: VV002 - Unit cost increase in FY20 is due to single procurement of final full decoy (payload plus flight assembly). Funding from VV002 in the FY 2020 President's Budget request was realigned to VV200, VV201, VV202, VV203, VV005, VV006, and VV003. Starting in FY21, payload procurement will be in VV005 and VV006, and flight assembly procurement will be in VV203.

VV003 - Engineering Changes and Logistics Support - Increase in FY20 ECP funding will support DLS hardware updates including Circuit Card Assembly (CCA) redesigns, Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) initialization improvements, Power Supply System (PSS) modernization. Increase in FY20 logistics funding will support maintenance of decoy and special purpose test equipment, non-recurring costs to produce engineering equipment, and configuration management tools for Flight Control Units, Propulsion Igniter Units, Thrust Control Units, Thermal Batteries, Spin Control Units, Rocket Motor Assemblies, Canister Assemblies, and Advanced Flight Assemblies.

VV830 - Funding is for Production Engineering support to the MK 234 Nulka Decoy, Nulka Kit Assemblies, Rocket Motor Assembly, Canister Assembly, Advanced Flight Assemblies, Nulka X/Y Payloads, and Advanced Nulka Payloads. Increases starting in FY21 are due to Production Engineering costs for new Nulka Payload Assembly (PU: VV005).

VV500 - An increase in FY21 funding from the FY 2020 President's Budget request to the FY 2021 President's Budget request allows for procurement of 8 pod units. As a result, mass model units are reduced from nine to four units. Additionally, this increase also facilitates Production Support activities to include: pre-installation work ups and documentation, updates to training materials, and sparing support.

VV005 - Funding has been added for procurement of Nulka-X/Y Payloads. The EW payload was developed under an ONR program that targets specific threats that the current payload on the Nulka decoy does not. The payload provides an advanced Electronic Warfare (EW) transmitter and increased signal processing capability.

VVINS - Funding is for the installation of Nulka Systems, and Fleet Modernization Program installs. Since the FY 2020 President's Budget request, FY20 funding increase is due to the requirement to procure additional platforms and associated development needed to install the Nulka system.

Description.val:
Program funds the procurement and installation of the MK53 Nulka System.

[NULKA SYSTEMS] Funds the procurement and installation of the MK53 Nulka Decoy Launching System (DLS).  The MK 53 DLS consists of a Decoy Launch Processer (DLP), launching power supplies and from two to six launchers depending on the ship class.  Each launcher is capable of storing and launching two Nulka decoys.  The MK 53 DLS provides the launch authorization and flight demands to the Nulka decoy when a Nulka engagement is initiated by the EW operator.  The MK 53 DLS has been installed on the CG 47, DDG 51, FFG 7, LSD 41, and LSD 49 Classes in prior years.  Installation of the MK 53 DLS on CVNs began in FY14 and it will be installed on eight carriers. Six of the final seven DLS units are being procured under BLI 5231. The last DLS will be procured under BLI 5530, which starts in FY20.

Note: Since the FY 2020 President's Budget request, the FY20 increase to installation cost is due to the requirement to procure additional platforms and associated development needed to install the Nulka system.
